div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,424 7,424] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD
div.p: BREMEN.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.
For Particulars see Advertisement below.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Suez about 23 February
R.M.S "Orotava" will leave Suez about 9 March.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said 26 February
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said 12 March
Egyptain Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer claimed, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 0/0 if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.p: CAPITAL: L. 3,000,000. RESERVE (ENVIRON) : L. 1,340,000.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about noon with Vienna express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and as to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 28 February, 14 March; 1, 11 & 25 April; 1, 9 & 22 May ; 6 June, 4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 28 February, 5 & 19 March, 4 p.m.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.

To Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 9 February, 9 March.
To Djibouti, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 20 Jan, 20 Feb., 4 p.m.
Winter Line. To Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 14 Feb., 14 March & 4 April
East African Line.
Departures from Suez: To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3 Feb., 6 March., 3 April..

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather to-day promises to be an improvement on yesterday. The humidity in the air is less and the barometer is rising. The morning was bright and cheerful.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
OBSERVATIONS BY SURVEY DEPARTMENT
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: BIRTH
div.p: Heaton,-On the 17th inet., at Moharen Bey, the wife of Mr. O, Stanley Heaton, of a son.

div.head: THE ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE
div.p: A Havas telegram from Algeciras, which we publish to-day, announces that Germany has refused to entertain the French proposal regarding the policing of Morocoo by French and Spanish officers selcted by the Sultan.

Germany bases her non pouumus attitude on the fact that to permit such a scheme would be oontrary to the internationalisation of the country and the equality of the Powers there. As the conference may come to pieces on this question it is important to consider it, especially in view of the new light thrown on the subject by the statements which I appeared in the "Times" of yesterday week. It will be remembered that a recent "inspired” communique to the German Press gave it to be understood that France had claimed the right to police the whole of Morocco, a claim against which Germany had protested, and would protest, on the ground that it infringed the principle of the Sultan’s independence, and would lead to the "Tunisification” of the She- reefian Empire. Now as the Paris correspondent of the "Times” pointed out yesterday week. M. Revoil has never made any each claim on behalf of h’s Government—we shall see, present¬ly, why not. Ail that France claims is, as M. Revoil has made it dear, the right to organise the policing of the ports, and it is round the problem of organizing the necessary police force for the seaports that the struggle is going on behind the screen of diplomatic decency inter-posed by the formal meetings over which the Duke of Almodovar presides.

Why is that particular problem the only one for which M. Revoil would have been likely to claim, as he has done, the right of France to find the necessary solution ? The answer is - simple enough. The penetration of the civilising influence in Morocco must proceed, as the . anatomists say, from without inwards. The fringe of Moroccan seaports formas the row of doors by which Moroccao communicates (in so far as she is compelled to do so) with Europe on the north and on the west These towns contain considerable European populations engaged in trader or owning laud in the vicinity. Outside the zone of the influence of these towns reigns immemorial chaos, which extends over the rest of the land, right away to the Algerian frontier on the east, and south¬wards to the sands of the Sahara. Can any sane person imagine that France has any desire to attempt the subjugation—for that it would have to be — manu military of an enormous country, absolutely unprovided with roads, and inhabited by fierce, fighting tribesmen, who dare not, if they could, grow more corn and other necessaries than they actually want, for fear of the rapacity either of neighbours or of the local governors in those of their districts where these feel themselves able to practice extortion ? Years hence the interior of Morocco may gradually yield to the process of more or less practise penetration; but for the present it is enough to attempt to civilise the coasts—a proofs of which European interests m the seaports have long been in sore need. Now, considering that Germany's interests in Marocco have been officially declared to be purely commercial, (though these amount to only about £90,000 worth of trade per annum) one might have supposed that such interests would have been admirably served by the prompt inauguration of a system which would guarantee the security of life and property in and around the ports. But not a bit of it: the German proposal, we are told, is that the Sultan shall do the work, with the assistance of the minor powers. That would mean, of course, that there would be no efficient organisation what¬ever. France, with her Algerian experience, with her Algerian prestige, is the obvious agent to be selected by Europe for the job; hot Germany, it seems, will not consent Wby? Because, as as it would appear, she prefers the continuance of the present state of things to a change which would put an everlasting veto upon the ambition which she cherishes, but does not avow, of securing a foothold on the Atlantic seaboard herself She knows that, for the present, that ambition cannot be realised, bat she holds on to it, knowing that every¬thing comes to those who know how to wait, and that, since she cannot get her own way yet, the next best thing is to keep the door open, and bide her time until circumstances, shall allow her to slip in. Those circumstances?, however, will hardly be present just yet But the German game scarcely bodes well for the success of the Morocco Conference.
